column4: hello guys ive tried to use screen but now i have 5 sockets on :( how can i close them :(( cant do anything with /etc/init.d/screen stop
Are you trying to terminate the screens along with their process, or just the screen itself?
typing 'screen -list' should bring up a list of the screens along with their PID. Attach to the screen with 'screen -x', then press 'CTRL+A+K'
You can also kill the process with 'kill [PID]', which will terminate both the process and the screen. This is a last resort though and is not recommended in any way.
CTRL+A+K is to kill the screen. CTRL+A+D is to detach from the screen.
The PID is the first number on the screen's name, on that one, it's 28187. I would not suggest killing the process unless it's absolutely necessary.
I don't know what to tell you, I would prefer not to just tell you to kill the processes, as you should be able to reattach to them...
Could you try just doing 'screen -r' with no extra paramaters? See if you connect to any of them?
Killing the processes will not damage screen. It will simply quit the screen like you were trying to do before.
Killing the screen would terminate the process anyways, they're pretty much the same.
Screens, if I recall, are private to the user they were started on. So, if you started screen on 'userA', 'userB' will not be able to view the screen.
You would have to start the screens again to regain access to them. Once the process is killed, the screen is gone too.
That's very odd. You should be able to just connect to them by typing 'screen -r [startOfName]', so I'm not sure why they wouldn't be working.
Good to hear, come back if you have any more issues.
